title: Fortescue boss dismisses PM's claim China no longer 'developing'
text:
"If there are any challenges with the WTO rules, it is the rules to consider not whether or not China is still a developing country."

China produced 928 million tonnes of steel in 2018 and Ms Gaines said it would go close to producing 1 billion tonnes for the first time in 2019.

Many analysts believe the Chinese steel industry is close to its peak production, but with its urbanisation rate at about 60 per cent in 2018, Ms Gaines said there was plenty more steel-intensive urbanisation to come.

''In terms of the steel peak, for most developed countries it is only when the urbanisation rate gets above 70 per cent, so it is quite a long time yet before China gets to that rate of 70 per cent,'' she said.

"It could be decades to come yet before they reach that urbanisation rate.

''It is critical that across government, business and all stakeholders there is a recognition of that contribution and how we best sustain that trading partnership for the future."

The Chinese embassy in Canberra responded angrily to Mr Morrison's suggestion in September that China's trade arrangements should reflect its new found status as a global power.

"The assertion of China being a 'newly developed economy' by the Australian side doesn’t hold much water. It is both one-sided and unfair. And it is basically an echo of what the US has claimed," the embassy said in a statement on September 26.

Advertisement

"It is true that China, through its own efforts, has made remarkable achievements in economic and social development over the past decades and become the world's second largest economy.

"However, there is still a big gap between China and the developed countries in terms of overall development level. China still has a long way to go to achieve full modernisation."

Fortescue is bidding for two iron ore leases in Guinea's Simandou mountains.

Ms Gaines said the competitive nature of the bidding process limited her from extrapolating on Fortescue's interest in Guinea, where Rio Tinto found controversy over payments allegedly made to a political lobbyist in 2011.

''We know there is high grade iron ore there ... so it makes sense to look at where those high grade iron ore deposits are,'' she said.

"At some point those deposits will be developed so having an interest in that we think does make strategic sense.''

Rio tried to sell its stake in Simandou to Chinalco in October 2016, but that deal fell through, suggesting Fortescue may have other options for entering Simandou if it fails in the current bidding process.
description: Fortescue chief Elizabeth Gaines says China is still developing, in a rejection of Scott Morrison's call for China to be considered a newly developed country.
